question: Question_01_(k)
statement:
The quadratic approximation of a demand function q(p) at p=10 is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}T_2(p)=2-4(p-10)+3(p-10)^2.\end{align*}

Calculuate $\epsilon(10)$ where $\epsilon(p)$ is the price-elasticity of
demand.
hints:
Recall that the formula for the price-elasticity of demand is

$\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{p\cdot q'(p)}{q(p)}$.

The problem requests that we fine $\epsilon(10)$ which is given by

$\displaystyle \epsilon(10) = \frac{10\cdot q'(10)}{q(10)}$

so we need to find the values $q(10)$ and $q'(10)$. How can we do this
with the given information?

Recall that the quadratic approximation is just the second degree Taylor
polynomial given by

\begin{align*}\displaystyle T_{2}(p) = q(10) + q'(10)(p - 10) + \frac{1}{2}q''(10)(p-10)^{2}.\end{align*}

Compare this with the given to find the unknown values as given in the
previous hint.
